unit.label: Act I, Scene VIII
unit.title: SCENE VIII. A field of battle between the Roman and the Volscian camps

conventions.dash_policy: classify em/en/hyphen as separate tokens; all dash types normalize to "-"
conventions.bracket_policy: strip underscores and outer brackets from stage spans

spans.text: THE TRAGEDY OF CORIOLANUS
ACT I, SCENE VIII — A field of battle between the Roman and the Volscian camps
SCENE VIII. A field of battle between the Roman and the Volscian camps
Alarum, as in battle. Enter Martius and Aufidius at several doors.
I’ll fight with none but thee, for I do hate thee
Worse than a promise-breaker.
We hate alike.
Not Afric owns a serpent I abhor
More than thy fame and envy. Fix thy foot.
Let the first budger die the other’s slave,
And the gods doom him after!
If I fly, Martius,
Hollo me like a hare.
Within these three hours, Tullus, Alone I fought in your Corioles’ walls,
And made what work I pleased. ’Tis not my blood
Wherein thou seest me masked. For thy revenge
Wrench up thy power to th’ highest.
Wert thou the Hector
That was the whip of your bragged progeny,
Thou shouldst not scape me here.
Here they fight, and certain Volsces come to the aid of Aufidius.
Officious and not valiant, you have shamed me
In your condemned seconds.
Martius fights till they be driven in breathless. Aufidius and Martius exit, separately.
